1042842519845781504.text:
1/ Relation & rollup are the most powerful features in Notion! This thread is a 3min intro guide 

First of all, the world runs on relational databases! Once cutting edge 70s tech, invented by IBM/famously forgotten – til Larry Ellison/Oracle sold it to every bank and gov pic.twitter.com/qnfB9n1VwB

1042848027671556096.text:
10/ Hope that gives you a good sense of relation & rollup? They're one of the most powerful features in Notion.

More ideas:
- Tasks & projects
- Companies & contacts
- Job applicants & interviewers
...
Have fun and stay organized! 

Full guide: https://www.notion.so/notion/Database-102-relation-rollup-fd56bfc6a3f0471a9f0cc3110ff19a79 …pic.twitter.com/wx4K6EQ1TT

1042846579906928640.text:
9/ Lastly, how can we see the total amount ALL customers have spent? 

Move your mouse towards the bottom of a column → you'll see a "Calculate" button → choose SUM. 

Calculate and rollup are a powerful combo pic.twitter.com/KgpyJxyrWf

1042846331662786561.text:
8/ There are 14 kinds of rollups as of today:

Show Original (as known as a lookup), Min, Max, Range (max minus min), Count All... full list: https://www.notion.so/notion/Database-102-relation-rollup-fd56bfc6a3f0471a9f0cc3110ff19a79#83fcae334047471ea6ed88029d417b70 …

With relation & rollup, you can solve problems that typically only programmers can solve pic.twitter.com/5csO3HsvkM

1042845728362491904.text:
7/ Naturally you'll wonder: how much did Susan spend – in total? 

For that you'll need a rollup!

In the Customers database, add a property/column → set it to Rollup → set relation to Ordered Products → set property to Price → set Calculate to SUM.

Powerful right? pic.twitter.com/VanAOY10n7

1042844947815096322.text:
6/ Notice another column automatically created for you in the Products database? 

Relations are two-way in Notion, so when you add "Tank-top" as an order for Susan, we inversely adds "Susan" as a customer in "Tank-top". Super handypic.twitter.com/za89pP5hTO

1042844525633273856.text:
5/ Now we can see all of Susan's orders in a table! 

If you want to remove/edit one: 
- Click to open an order as a editable page (say, you want to change the price of a product on the fly).
- Click on the red circle to remove an order.

It's keyboard-friendly too pic.twitter.com/2AwW27jnKf

1042844269285847040.text:
4/ How to tell the database that Susan ordered "Khaki pants" + "Tank top" 

Click the Ordered Products cell on the Susan row→ pick a product → confirm with Enter to add those related pages.

(Tip: add multiple products at once by clicking on the blue circle )pic.twitter.com/Er32jwyYOX

1042843526923313152.text:
3/ First step, set up a relation 

In the Customers database, add a property/column → set it to Relation → select the Products database.

Now a customer can relate to one (or more) products! We're going to name this relation "Ordered Products" to keep track.pic.twitter.com/NGndruepm6

1042843160341172224.text:
2/ Let's start with an example 

Imagine you have two databases: customers and products, and you want to them to work together to find out:

- Who bought what?
- How much did they spend, total?

(Example page: https://www.notion.so/notion/Database-102-relation-rollup-fd56bfc6a3f0471a9f0cc3110ff19a79#19baed2a495f4655bac7f4362a582b32 …)pic.twitter.com/NwE8zCdXos
